text: at basf's agricultural facilities in
Research Triangle Park North Carolina
insects gets star treatment scientists
are pampering their prized pests only to
sacrifice them later as part of the
company's approach to evaluating new
insecticides that could help improve
crop protection according to basf's
william fisher who heads insect
propagation the same kinds of insects
that are hard to kill on the farm can be
surprisingly difficult to raise in the
lab hence the five-star accommodations
in the insectary species of bugs are
housed in chambers with optimal
temperatures and light to promote
egg-laying and growth and no pampering
is complete without special meals the
southern green stinkbug for example
dines on green beans soybeans and
peanuts when BASF scientists are ready
to evaluate their insecticides the bugs
are introduced to test plants and
together they enter a machine that
sprays the given insecticide researchers
observe how effective the treatments are
in killing the pests but sparing the
plants for humans these efforts could
yield a more robust food supply for the
sacrificial bugs unfortunately this meal
will be their last I'm melody
Baumgardner for chemical and engineering
news
